conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we'll follow these steps.
The p-T graph plots pressure (p) against temperature (T). It provides the relationship between pressure and temperature at different points.
The V-T graph plots volume (V) against temperature (T). It provides the relationship between volume and temperature at different points.
From the p-T graph: At 200 K, the pressure is 0.5 x 10⁵ Pa. At 600 K, the pressure is 1.5 x 10⁵ Pa.
From the V-T graph: At 200 K, the volume is 2 m³. At 400 K, the volume is 2 m³. At 600 K, the volume is 3 m³.
The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.
We can use the ratio form of the ideal gas law to find the pressure at 600 K: (P1 V1)/T1 = (P2 V2)/T2.
Using the data from the graphs: P1 = 0.5 x 10⁵ Pa (at 200 K), V1 = 2 m³ (at 200 K), T1 = 200 K, V2 = 3 m³ (at 600 K), T2 = 600 K.
Plug these values into the ratio form of the ideal gas law: (0.5 x 10⁵ x 2)/200 = (P2 x 3)/600.
Simplify and solve for P2: 1 x 10⁵/200 = 3P2/600.
The pressure of the gas at 600 K is 100,000 Pa (or 1.0 x 10⁵ Pa).
